In comfort and in seating, to make one relax.
For most, 'tis standing room, I do declare,
Unless thou hast the means, to pay for a chair.
Or, peradventure, should the balcony be free,
Then mayhap, thou may sit, and watch the show with glee.

But fear not, good sir! For sound, they have in store,
A quality, that doth rival, any other before.
So, if thou art in search, of melodic delight,
Then, to The House of Blues, thou shouldst take flight."

"Pizza Hut. No need to say more. You know what you're getting. But I gotta give props to the crew at the carry-out joint I hit up sometimes. They're always friendly, trying their best with what they got. Gotta give 'em a thumbs up. Three stars, that's the law."

"Large dinner parties, A+ experiences. This time, reservation for two in the dining room, happy birthday dinner. Restaurant full and busy, seated upon arrival. Drink orders taken promptly, then waited...

Salad and entree orders taken, salad arrived quick. Waitress assigned to 10-top table, chef/owner hosting, ignored us rest of dinner. Flagged down bus person for water refills, asked for additional bread, waited for entrees, requested water refills, final request for check. 

Food was okay, angel hair with tomato sauce, gnocchi, good portions, served steaming hot."

"First off, the spice bouquet makes its presence known. Memories of its broth, cleverly seasoned with cloves, bay leaves, coriander seeds, and cardamom. Variations on the same theme. The Classics are more polished, with cleaner cuts of meat. The Adventurers, on the other hand, have a less refined beef anatomy, with juicy flanks and crunchy tripe. If the lack of asepsis bothers you, best to avoid the bathroom. I deduct a star for this reason."
"Pasta, good. Wine, good. But can's trust Italian restaurant with Hershey's syrup on tiramisu. Sorry."

"Came here on a freebie from a radio contest. Not sure I'd have paid for it otherwise. Steak was decent, but overpriced. They do have a sample platter, though - filet, Kobe, and New York strip for around 70 bucks. Kobe was solid, but it's hard to mess up a good cut of meat. Mashed potatoes were alright, tried the trio and the truffle and lobster version was the best. Wouldn't come back, too many better options around."

"Capriotti's makes a damn fine sandwich, but they're overpriced and stuck in the past. No whole wheat bread? Get with the times, boys. Every other joint's got it. Fire House, Subway, Port of Subs, Quiznos - they all offer a healthier option. Come on, Capriotti's, step up your game."

"Hark! Doth thou seek to reach thy class with haste,
When foul weather doth make journeying a waste?
Then fear not, for MTD doth provide a way,
To traverse distance, come what may.

But alas, their buses oft run late, I pray,
So choose thy route with wisdom and dismay.
For though they be free to students, 'tis no jest,
To arrive too late, and thus be at a loss.

So heed my words, fair scholar, and make haste,
To choose a bus that doth arrive with grace.
And thus, thou shalt reach thy destination,
In time, and with no cause for consternation."

"Hark, fair friends! I've been to this place afore,  
And yet, my love for it doth not grow.  
The antipasti platter, a middling fare,  
The mozzarella, good; the bruschetta, too much pesto to bear.  
The calamari, alas! Not crispy enough,  
The chicken marsala, a mediocre dish, I do declare.  
The mashed potatoes, a saving grace,  
But I, a fool, didst stray from my usual pasta pace.  
The service, always excellent, doth shine,  
A beacon of hope, in this culinary decline."

"O, wilt thou not require the English tongue?
For we can look after ourselves, my dear.
We are a nation, strong and free.

Fie upon the cultural cringe, I say,
'Tis time to cast it aside, and seize the day.
For we are capable, and we shall prevail,
In all things, great and small, we shall not fail."

"Went to Einstein's for breakfast, Sunday mornin', just before nine. Line was out the door, but we decided to wait. Moved pretty quick, only took thirteen minutes to order and pay. Dining area's decent, so we found a table easy. Food came four minutes later. Had the applewood bacon and cheddar egg sandwich on a plain bagel. Hot and good, but a bit pricey."

"Met up with a buncha folks at this joint. Twenty or so. Got to try a few dishes. Some were good, some weren't. They got European beers, that's a plus. Took 'em a while to bring out the grub, even though we booked ahead. Family-run spot, mom, dad, and the kid were all workin'. Good to support the locals, I reckon."

"Came here for the first time today. Place is decent if you're hankerin' for some boba without the hassle of goin' to Chinatown. Got the boba milk tea with jelly - tasted like volcano tea, so I was pleased. My boyfriend got the taro smoothie, said it was subpar. Guess it's hit or miss. Docked off points for lackluster selection and uninspired atmosphere. Inside's cramped, plain, and dull. Feels like a grab-and-go joint, not a spot to linger. Would be nice if they sold snacks too."

"In fairest Summerlin, where golf courses abound,
A fundraiser brought me to The Ridges profound.
Amidst the exclusivity, my excitement did grow,
To play the links where Jack Nicklaus' art did flow.

Alas, the heat did swelter, and the course did lack,
The lushness of greens, and the fairways did attack.
Recently punched, the holes did not yet heal,
Leaving the round less than ideal, I must reveal.

The clubhouse, too, did fail to impress,
With service cold, and no warmth to address.
No purchases made, my disappointment did grow,
For friendlier folk, I shall seek, ere I go.

Yet still, each hole held promise, with views so fine,
Of homes elegant, and the Strip's shining shrine.
I shall return, and hope for better fate,
To see the course flourish, and its beauty create."
"Salads, good. Jumbo shrimp, nice. Dressings, unique. Lime ranch, great. Customer service, poor. Unhelpful, yeah."

"Hark! I've been to New York, where I didst partake
Of their most famous dish, a pie they call pizza.
But lo, my friends, the pizza I didst eat
Was nowhere near the real deal, alack!

We didst order the NY style, with high hopes
But alas, 'twas merely passable, naught more.
The establishment was pleasant, the service good
But I fear I shall not return, forsooth."

"I wouldn't have bothered with oil changes for a while if it wasn't for this joint. One-stop shop for oil changes and car washes, plus a Wendy's next door for a bite to eat. They've expanded their services, doing headlight replacements and belt changes now. Last time I went, I got an oil change, new air filter, and car wash for $47 after tax. They also do basic car washes for $3.99 and super washes for $7.99. I've only ever gotten the basic wash, and I've always found things they missed, so their quality isn't impressive. But it's convenient to have everything done in one spot. They have a 48-hour guarantee on their washes, and when you get work done, they give you a 'limited time' coupon for additional work. Not a bad deal."

A fair tavern, John's place doth be,
With decor neat and clean, for all to see.
The victuals, average they may be,
Yet, sliders, chicken or burger, doth please me.
Mario's Pizza menu, through a hallway connected,
Or bar menu, limited, yet sufficient, erected.
Drink specials, often there doth lie,
And TV's, plenty, for sporting events, doth provide.
Service, good, though at times, doth slip,
Regulars, mostly, from nearby, doth rip.
Convenient, aye, and pleasant, too,
For those who seek a local brew.

"Fair Gertrude's, where we didst break our fast,
And Chihuly's wondrous works, didst feast our eyes.
In foreign lands, we seek the gardens rare,
And here, with breakfast served, our hearts didst cheer.

My comrade and I, didst taste the sammies sweet,
Despite the name, that doth my senses greet.
The coffee, strong and bold, didst please my mind,
But oft, the cup, with liquid gold, didst decline.

The patio, fair and bright, didst host our meal,
And from the cold, our spirits didst reveal.
A pleasant breeze, didst gently kiss our skin,
As we didst dine, in sunshine warm and kin."

Last week, we chanced upon this eatery,
Whose popularity did our patience test.
A lengthy queue did deter us,
But then, they brought forth lechon kawali, fresh from the nest.

We stayed, and savored dishes rare,
Corned beef, potatoes, oxtail stew they did prepare.
The taste, oh so divine,
It made our bellies cheerful and fine.

In a bustling plaza, this place doth sit,
Amongst other victuals, a varied fit.
Its name, "Bahay na bato" doth imply,
That Filipinos hold neighbors dear, and nigh.

The cost, a meager sum, did please,
For two dishes, rice, and joy, did it release.

A store of fine wares, with choice selection fair,
Yet, alack, the staff doth lack in courtesy and care.
The elder folk, kind, gentle, and helpful be,
But youthful ones, discourteous, rude, and rough to see.
Loud talk of personal matters they do make,
And show annoyance, irk, and roll their eyes in disdain.
How strange, a high-end store, with staff so ill-bred,
That shoppers suffer thus, and leave in discontent and dread.

Sitting here, son playing. Music blasts, gotta holler to talk. Asked 'em to turn it down, they did, then cranked it back up. Inappropriate jams come on, gotta tell staff to switch it off. Don't want my kid hearing about a$$ and twerking, know what I mean? Besides that, not bad.

"In sooth, the Boozery doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain zest that one might expect from its location. The bar itself, though small, doth make up for it with outdoor seating, a pleasant enough space. But alas, the confines of its walls do cramp its style, and the drinks, though priced fair, doth not offer much in the way of variety or flair. In short, the Boozery is naught but an average tavern, neither here nor there, a place to pass the time, but not a place to linger long."

"A gathering of friends, fair maidens all,
I planned at this humble abode, ere night did fall.
Small, unassuming, blink and ye may miss,
Parking, alas, doth pose a problem, nay, a test.
A few spots in front, in back, perchance a few more,
Yet, full they be, good fortune doth thou seek no more.

Menu, simple, hearty dishes, comfort food,
Meatloaf, burgers, fish, salads, as they should.
Veggie burger, fries, my choice, naught to boast,
Morning Star, a common fare, no surprise, no toast.
Service, kind, attentive, yet, another try,
Brunch, perhaps, worth a venture, we shall espy."

"Hark! How loud the tavern doth resound!
A place most fitting for beer, sports, and grub,
Yet, alas! Conversation doth suffer, methinks.

The ale selection, outstanding, by my troth!
Food, well-prepared and tasty, doth abound.
But, lo! The service doth lag, and I do ponder,
Why doth it take so long? Our meals, now cold,
Do lose their charm, yet still, the gravy fries
And macaroni, both most flavorful, doth shine.

Alas! I dwell in Glendale, far away,
So shall not journey thitherward again,
Yet, wouldst recommend this tavern, to my friends,
Who seek a merry place to watch a game, and doth partake
Of fine ale, brewed with skill and care, no doubt."

"Hark! What news is this? A place so fair and bright,
Within walking distance to all that's good and right.
Notre Dame, Old Montreal, Chinatown, and more,
A plethora of delights for eyes to devour.

The room, it was spacious, with ceilings high,
A king-size bed, and kitchen, did catch mine eye.
The staff, they were friendly, and provided with grace,
An extra cot, without any additional cost or trace.

Internet, free of charge, they did provide,
A code, upon check-in, did they not deny.
Breakfast, continental, with toast, croissants, and fruit,
Coffee, too, did they offer, with a smile so cute.

But alas, two beds we requested, and one we did find,
A room with only one, our hopes did unwind.
We spoke to the desk, but rooms to switch, they had none,
Yet, a cot, they provided, at no extra cost, 'twas done.

Towels, they did smell, a slight inconvenience, indeed,
Parking, $22 a day, and valet, it must be decreed.
If in thy car, something thou dost need,
Concierge, thou must go through, with speed."

"A rarity, this three-star review doth be,
For this Las Vegas buffet, a sight to see.
I, Shakespeare, doth say, 'tis the sole
Buffet I've visited, thus no comparison doth unfold.

Amidst the Strip, I wandered, lost in thought,
When hunger pangs struck, and I sought
A place to sate my appetite, and thus I found
This buffet, with options diverse, profound.

Gourmet, they were not, yet still they pleased,
My taste buds, with flavors unreleased.
Crab legs, oh how grand, worth every penny,
Twenty dollars, a steal, for such a bounty.

Prime rib, mashed potatoes, spicy tuna too,
Were standouts, among the rest, anew.
Salad bar, just average, alas, a shame,
Desserts, likewise, failed to stir the flame.

Yet, still, a good deal, for those who crave,
A hearty meal, at a price most brave.
The atmosphere, tacky, true, yet within
Imperial Palace, expectations spin."

"Methinks I've lodged here twice, and both times, my chamber hath been far different.  One side of this inn be renovated, and verily, 'tis a vast disparity.  My love and I didst occupy a room with a kingly bed, and 'twas well-appointed, with a fine bathing chamber.  I didst reserve once more, with my female companions, and our chambers didst contain two double beds, in a state of disrepair, with aged furnishings and carpet.  If thou art traveling with friends, and doth not intend to spend much time within thy chamber, then this place mayhap shall suffice, by virtue of its site and cost.  Alas, there be other drawbacks; to wit, the gymnasium doth require a fee, and the pool area doth teem with multitudes...'Tis a challenge to procure a recliner.  The games of chance didst prove enjoyable, yet the beverage service doth lag somewhat."

"Methinks my hopes were raised too high, fair friends,
For fare that failed to impress, alack and alas!
'Twas passable, naught more, and naught worth the price,
Yet service good, a saving grace, by my troth!"
"Pizza and wings, delivered. Vibes from the staff, weird. Unpleasant. Called in, expecting cheer. Not happening. Last time, till the free coupon. Not bad, better than Hut."

"Hark, good sir, Hakkasan lies within the Grand MGM. Our group didst venture forth, with haste, to beat the clock, ere the witching hour of one didst strike. By fortune's grace, we didst make it, and found the entrance free of charge. The bouncers, kind and courteous, didst ease our passage into the club with gentle efficiency. Alas, the dance floor, small and cramped, didst hinder our movements, so that we could scarce dance at all. 'Twas body to body, a tight press, and naught but a moderate crowd, I fear, didst make the experience less than pleasant. Forsooth, I wouldst not desire to be present, were the DJ of renown, as the throng wouldst surely swell, and chaos wouldst ensue. My memories, alack, do fail me, for drink didst cloud mine eyes, and I recall naught but the confines of the place, and the strictures of the guards, who didst bid us move, when e'er we didst find a space to dance."

"Been here twice for eyebrow threading. No appointments, just walked in. Desk attendant, professional. Brow threader, excellent job. But could work on customer service. Didn't ask how I wanted my brows or say a word. Still, good enough to come back."

"Place wasn't bad for a buffet. Food was legit, spices on point. Variety was solid, but I didn't know what the hell half of it was. Might hit up an actual Indian joint next time, get just one dish, like chicken marsala or curry. That way, I can really taste the flavors."
"Pricey, but Gandhi's down the street is cheaper.  Food was good, not great.  Better atmosphere than most Indian joints."

"Verily, I must confess, I didst enjoy myself at dinner, 'Twas a grand time, indeed! The space, most wondrous fair, Didst seem as trendy as they didst strive to be. Dancers, scantily clad, didst strut and sway Above us, as we dined, in gay abandon.

But, alack! The hostesses, full of pride, Didst vex me sorely, with their haughty mien. A reservation, I didst have, 'Tis true, Yet they, in error, didst claim it not to be. And thus, we waited, for an hour or more, In vain, for tables, that were plain to see.

Our server, kind and gentle, didst attend To our needs, with grace and cheerfulness. The food, not bad, but not of highest quality, A black cod appetizer, well-cooked, I found, While crab cakes, merely passable, didst seem. Fried shrimp, a delight, and steaks, as expected, From Morton's, solid, standard fare, unremarked.

In conclusion, fun it was, but, in this town, With restaurants galore, of high renown, I doubt, my friends, I'll return, ere long."

"This joint's got good grub, but it ain't my cup of tea. Service was top-notch, that's for sure. Food? Eh, it was alright. Hash and taters were too salty, couldn't finish 'em. Stick with the waffles and pancakes, they looked decent. Can't say I'd recommend it, unless you like your food drowning in seasoning. It's a fun spot, though."

In days of yore, when hunger pangs did strike,
I chanced upon a place, a breadwinner's delight,
A Panera clone, they say, but now 'tis true,
Their own creations bloom, and that's a boon or two.

I sampled late their Italian veggie fare,
Tasty indeed, but pricey, I must declare,
For portion size, a meager offering, I feared,
Leaving me still peckish, though sated, my dear.

The ambiance, pleasant, Wi-Fi free,
Yet service, lacking, a blemish, I do see,
Still, a decent choice, if sandwiches be thy quest,
But pasta dishes, alack, lack zest.

"Sometimes, amidst the fancy eats, ya crave somethin' plain. This joint fit the bill. Not bad for a cafe, especially considerin' the limited lunch options on a lazy Sunday. Reminded me of Cheesecake Factory, what with the extensive menu and friendly staff. I went for the Fried Chicken and Mashed Potatoes. The chicken was a tad salty, but the potatoes were decent. Had a Strawberry Martini since they were out of Pear. Hubby's cheeseburger and fries were satisfactory. I'd return if I had to, but there's better grub nearby."

"A fair buffet for locals, methinks, though 'tis not worth the cost, anon. For two, the price doth exceed five and twenty crowns, a sum most steep, indeed. Yet, free for me, thanks to my love's generosity. 

Upon a Friday, we didst venture forth to taste their seafood delights. Alas, naught stood out, save for the crab, which was quite good, by Jove! Our server, merry and bright, didst attend to us with haste. But, alack, the sushi, cold and woeful, failed to impress. And shrimp, once cold, didst lose its former luster, I do confess. 

Hush puppies, small and crispy, were too salty, verily. Fried catfish, though tasty, lacked crunch, its batter soft and limp. Desserts, too, didst disappoint. Carrot cake, so dry, didst crumble at the touch. Chocolate fudge, with icing sweet, didst leave me unsatisfied, I do entreat. 

Crab, the star of the feast, didst please, and presentation of shellfish dishes, a delight. All else, middling, at best, I do declare. A place for families, mayhap, or those with means, seeking a casual, indulgent affair."

"Pasta portion? Huge. Didn't need apps, but got 'em anyway. Spaghetti with meatballs, classic. If they can't nail it, bad sign. Noodles, al dente. Meatballs, juicy. Stuffed from cured meats and flatbread pizza. Came back later, drunk, for more pizza. Everyone else did too."

"In days of yore, I penned my thoughts on this place,
To warn of woe, and food poisoning's bitter taste.
But now, I dine anew, and with joy do say,
Their vegetarian fare, doth please mine appetite.
And though the entrees, may not be the best,
Their rice, doth make up for it, in quantity and zest.
For working class Asians, like meself, do adore,
A full bowl of rice, and here, 'tis found in store.
So, highly do I rate this place, for its good cheer,
And generous portions, that doth bring us near."
"Vegetarian fajitas, ten bucks. Not a bad deal, but you don't get much tofu. Jack Astor's got better fajitas in every way. Overall, not bad, but I wouldn't order 'em again."

"Burgers, I'm a sucker for 'em. But it takes a damn good one to impress me. Indulge, they think they can, but they always screw up the temp. Hate that. Outback's got the right idea - undercook 'em all, I don't give a damn. And for Christ's sake, add some salt to the beef. Happy hour deals, now we're talkin'."

"Food was top-notch. Service, too. Get the sides - lentils and hummus, both excellent. Ran outta pita bread, but they hooked me up with more. Dessert? Strawberry bar, can't remember the name, but it was damn good. Ordered the Good Earth sandwich, fresh ingredients, but the sauce was off. Guacamole sandwich, better, but red sauce too sweet. Split 'em with a buddy, both agreed. Tree of Life, the other vegan option, went well with the boys."

"Lifetime's got top-notch facilities, no question. But let's talk about what really goes down in the men's locker room. I'm not kidding, this place gets wild after hours. I've seen a 55-year-old dude blow-drying his junk not once, but twice, while I was at the sink next to him. My friend was on his left, and this guy was straight up sandwiched between us, buck naked, stretching and blow-drying like it was nobody's business. I bailed on the gym, scared shitless. And it gets better. Another time, two dudes in their 30s were slapping each other's asses with towels, buck naked, chasing each other around the gym. They damn near knocked me over. Now, I ain't homophobic, but come on, there's a time and a place. And apparantly, Lifetime's the spot. Proceed with caution."

"Methinks my hopes were set too high, fair friends,
Let us begin with the good, ere we descend
To criticisms. A spacious place, indeed,
With ample parking and modern decor, 'twas seen.
Great service, too, from the single soul
Who tended the front of the house, in truth, he did strive.

"Chicken red curry, papaya salad, BBQ chicken,
Pad thai, and sweet rice, we ordered, forthwith.
The rice, alack, was soggy and o'ercooked,
In a plastic bag, it came, my heart did sink.

"BBQ chicken, a piece of breast, marinated
In dried curry rub, it seemed, and not a trace
Of BBQ flavor, nay, 'twas pan-fried, I say,
And thus, my friend, I did not like it, in sooth.

"Papaya salad, too salty, lacking lime zest,
Dried peanuts, tiny bits, throughout, did not impress.
Authentic, it was not, Americanized, I fear,
Yet my kids, they loved it, their sophisticated palate clear.

"Chicken red curry, bamboo shoots and curried veg,
Lacked flavor, the sauce, too bland, methought it could beg
A dash of fish sauce, perchance, to elevate,
But nay, 'twas just okay, my friends, fate.

"Pad thai, my children loved it, a joy to see,
Yet for me, the search continues, authentic Thai,
In Arizona, a quest, it seems, in vain,
For now, adieu, dear friends, till next we meet again."

"Manager took care of our bill, no fuss. Second time issues with service. First time, no water, no bill. Tonight, food to wrong people, cold. Told 'em we didn't want it, no attitude. Great customer service, but two strikes in a row. Comfortable seats, nice tables, screen, atmosphere, bar - good. Dining experience - bad. Rather focus on movie than what's wrong. Bottom line: Snacks and drinks in big purse, enjoy the show."

"Hark, what place is this? A haven of delight,
With space enough to dance through half the night.
The decor, a feast for mine eyes doth make,
And bartenders, friendly as can be, they do partake.
Alas, the men that here do gather, lacking wit,
Yet still, a place to don thy finest, and dance with glee, 'tis fit."

"Hark! A soiree within, most wondrous to behold,
Cool decor doth please the eye, a volcano doth unfold.
Burgers, better than yon joint, doth reign supreme,
Average fare, yet worth the cost, doth gleam."
"Roberto's, it's a joint I used to love. Good food, but not great anymore. Been to Mexico, had some real good street tacos. Now, it's just average. Still good, but not what it used to be."

"Methinks I've visited this place twice ere now,
And found the servitude most courteous and kind.
The ambiance, relaxed and lacking in formality, doth please mine eyes.

The pizza, alas! doth leave much to be desired.
I've sampled diverse sorts, yet found not one to my liking.
The sauces, dear friend, didst not impress me, nor the crust's texture or flavor.
But lo! their other dishes, such as sides, salads, and soups, didst delight mine taste buds.
I do confess, my curiosity doth stir,
To partake of their menu's other offerings, anon.
So, shall I return? Aye, verily, though not for the pizza, mark thee well."

"Good joint, good vibes, and solid service. But the bread? Meh. They're going for that heavy, wet stuff, which ain't my cup of tea. Just found Wildflower Bread Co., though. Their bread's got the right stuff - light, dry, but still juicy and snappy."

"We found this joint's lunch buffet by chance on our last day in Vegas.  It followed some rough times at Studio Cafe.  For a set price, it's not a bad deal considering how much grub costs in this town.  The dining room was colder than a witch's heart, but our server was top-notch.  She saw us shaking like leaves and offered us coffee and tea.  Kept 'em filled too."

"Tucked away in the Palazzo shops, this humble wine bar pours decent drinks and boasts a solid selection in its adjacent store. Prices are steep, but that's Sin City for you. Glassware leaves much to be desired - think cheap hotel banquet styles. Service, however, is top-notch. They keep your glass full."

"A merry spot for games of sport, where energy doth abound,
But alas, the speedball field doth lie in disrepair,
And officials, once keen, now doth seem so lax,
In their duties, as if they didst not care.

Yet, on the bright side, they didst repair my gun,
And cleansed it well, without any fee to be done.
I wouldst visit oft, if they didst mend their fields,
And hire refs of skill, with hearts that yield.
Then wouldst this place be worthy of five stars,
And praise from all, near and far, in Mars."

"Went to the Block & Grinder, heard good things. Food, 4-5 stars. Atmosphere and service, 2 stars. Cramped space, no waiter assigned. Waited 12 minutes, finally got a waiter. Slow service, but friendly. Pimento cheese appetizer, delicious. Ribs, lean and tender, top-notch. Would return, try a weeknight, hoping for better service. Want to try cocktails too."

"Hark! How oft I roam the verdant paths of Papago,
A place most fair and near my humble abode.
'Tis not my love for it that doth impel me thither,
But proximity and ease of access doth afford.

The trails, they doth not challenge, nor doth test
My mettle, yet doth provide a gentle quest.
In safety, I doth stroll, without a care,
Unless, perchance, a misstep doth ensnare.

The park, it doth gleam, in neatness and in grace,
And views of Phoenix, Tempe, and Scottsdale doth embrace.
Birds of a feather, doth flit and flutter by,
A sight most wondrous, doth catch mine eye.

For novice hikers, a haven, doth Papago prove,
A place to take the little ones, or thy loyal groove.
When seek thou fresh air, on a quiet morn or eve,
Papago, 'tis the place, thy spirit to retrieve."

"Methinks the townsfolk didst speak most highly of this establishment, praising their burgers with great zeal. And thus, I didst venture forth to partake of their culinary delights, not once, but twice, to ensure that my initial impression was not amiss. Alas, both experiences left me sorely disappointed, for the victuals didst lack the very essence of flavor, a quality that doth elevate the humblest of dishes to new heights. Aye, I didst sample both their burger and steak, and found them to be devoid of any discernible taste, a shortcoming that doth leave me in utter dismay."

"Hark! Bed Bath & Beyond, a store of woe,
With prices high and parking space low.
I do not oft shop there, save when
A coupon doth grace my hand with twenty percent off, then.

In search of Egyptian Cotton's sweet scent,
I ventured forth to this place of commerce bent.
Alas, they had it not, nor pots of worth,
Calphalon, indeed, yet too dear for my purse.

A shower curtain liner and candles twain,
Didst I purchase, still, a pot I must seek elsewhere in vain."

"Methinks I was most eager to dine herein,
But alas, my expectations were not met within.
We didst partake of frisee salad and lobster bisque,
Both dishes didst please mine taste buds, 'twas quite a trick.
A half-bottle of red wine didst accompany our feast,
And in truth, 'twas worth the cost, I do confess.
But alack, my love for Craftsteak doth end here,
Forsooth, the flat iron steak didst not impress me dear.
Nor didst the surf and turf, a ribeye and lobster tail,
In sooth, I have had better, and that doth not fail.
I am from Texas, where beef doth reign supreme,
And thus, my standards for steak are quite extreme.
The rolls, they didst not live up to their renown,
Good, perchance, but naught special, I doth own.
Hartz Chicken, their yeast rolls, dost rival these,
And thus, my friends, my words of praise doth cease."

"Downtown hotel. Not the Cal. Can't stand that joint. Makes me itch, like a bad case of crabs. Happy Faye, happy stay, I say. Standard rooms, nothing special. But the staff, they're good eggs. Always helpful, always friendly. And the 24-hour coffee shop? Decent grub, reasonable prices. Even got some Hawaii-friendly options. Not too shabby."

"Methinks this place doth merit three and a half stars, fair friends. The decor, it doth please mine eyes, and the menu, it doth tantalize mine taste buds. But, alack, I found it a mite too showy for mine liking. Perchance 'tis the Vegas way? I didst enter, based on a recommendation, for the oxtail chili fries. Verily, they didst not disappoint. A plentitude of meat, and full of flavor, it doth make mine mouth to water at the mere thought. Aye, a must-try, forsooth! I also didst partake of their summer special, the Manga burger. Alas, 'twas but mediocre, o'erwhelmed by sauce, and thus, the burger's true essence didst evade mine palate. To cleanse mine palette, I didst imbibe the matcha green tea milk shake. Delicious, indeed! Mayhap, I am spoiled by the burger joints of LA, yet, Bachi Burger, soon to open on Sawtelle, shall provide a worthy contest, anon."

"Penny-pincher, eh? Sahara's thy abode, then. 

Aged and crumbling, with shows most dire, 
Yet, 'tis a place of great renown, I do declare. 

The only woe, my friend, doth lie in this: 
'Tis somewhat distant from the strip's main bliss."

"When at the Renaissance tower I didst toil,
I'd come hither when too lazy to seek
Farther down the street a meal more fine.
For truth be told, their pizza doth lack sheen.
Or goodness, verily. But twice didst try
Their breakfast muffin, and both times 'twas divine.
Just the right amount of grease didst make it so,
And cheap, a bargain, indeed, didst show."

"Indian grub ain't my cup of tea, but if I gotta eat it, this joint's the place. They got some non-Indian dishes too, which is nice. Food's got some kick, real authentic stuff. Vegetarians'll find plenty to like here."
"Got a haircut. Liked it. Salon? Not my cup of tea. Too flashy for an old boy like me."

"Methinks 'tis a fair option for Indian victuals, good sir. Though I have not partaken in their luncheon spread, yet, what I have had, doth please mine taste. As a veggie, 'tis a comfort to know that naught but plant-based fare doth grace mine plate."

"Hark! The sushi here, a middling fare,
Neither great, nor bad, yet service fair.
But compared to those nearby, a lesser grade,
In quality and price, they do invade.
Thus, I shall return for Korean dish,
But for sushi, alas, my heart doth shrink."

"Hark! This place doth beckon us with wares of cloth and case,
Where bargains may be found, and deals of grace.
Their luggage selection doth impress, with choices many,
And carry-ons most fair, that doth make travel light.

But lo! On weekends, crowds do swarm this space,
Making shopping a chore, and trial of patience.
Best to come mid-week, when day doth break,
For fewer folk, and ease of navigation.

Yea, verily, the staff doth strive to keep this place neat,
And friendly faces doth greet thee at each turn.
So fear not, dear shopper, for all shall be well,
In this, thy quest for goods, and savings to tell."

"State employees, doing their job, helped me out. New to the state, needed a change of residency. No car, no driver's license, but a state ID would do. Lady at the front, kind and helpful. Line moved quick, faster than Chicago's DMV. With all the right papers, it's a fair experience."

"We spent four days here last August. It was an alright stay, but I doubt I'll be back unless they have a killer sale. The hotel's a bit worn down, but we had friends getting hitched at Mandalay Bay and we couldn't afford to stay there. So, we settled for this place since it was close by. Construction was a real pain in the ass though. They were banging away all weekend long. The pool area was tiny and nothing special. But hey, Club LAX was a plus. We got in for free since we were guests and it was a blast. No line, no fuss. We also appreciated the tram ride to Excalibur and Mandalay Bay. It beat walking in the scorching heat. Our room was cozy for two people, but any more and it would've been a squeeze. The food court could use some more options. All in all, you don't get much, but you don't pay much either."

"Hark! What fortune doth beset our quest for ale?
Three tables didst we try, yet still no luck didst prevail.
At last, the bar didst beckon us to come and sit,
But lo! They were out of lager, oh what a bitter fit!
A brewery without lager, how strange doth seem,
As if the moon didst hide its face from night's dark dream.
The victuals were passable, service poor, alack,
And elders, white as snow, didst fill the room with their chatter and lack."
"Modern hotel. Nice vibe. West side for 3G/4G. Pool's closed most of the day. WiFi'll cost ya. Drinks at poolside? Ridiculous."
"Food's good, but service? Forget about it. You'll be waiting forever. Make sure you've got nothing else planned for the night, 'cause you'll be stuck here, waiting for your drinks and grub."

"Hark! A tale of my journey to see the Panthers play,
A team of whom I know not, nor do I have a say.
Their fans, however, do abound, in numbers great,
A testament to their zeal, and love most elate.

Their stadium, a marvel of steel and stone,
Doth stand alone, save for the throngs that doth call it home.
On game days, 'tis surrounded by revelry and cheer,
But on other days, doth slumber, void of fear.

The facilities, quite modern and of high estate,
Do offer sustenance, both hot and cold, to sate.
The prices, fair and reasonable, a rarity indeed,
So, should thou find thyself nearby, do take a seat.

The fans, in joy and mirth, do gather round,
A family-friendly atmosphere, without a sound.
Tickets, too, are readily available, I do declare,
So, go and watch the Panthers, and banish all despair!"

"Food's been average, twice I've had it. Prices, though? Outta this world. Happy hour's decent, atmosphere's great, but that's about it. Unless you wanna impress someone with your bank account, no point in comin' here. Ocean Club's got better grub, that's for sure. Won't be back 'less someone gives me a gift cert. Too rich for my blood, even with a drink it's over 60 bucks, splurgin' territory. Not worth it."

"Methinks the grub doth taste most wondrous fair,
But, alas, the din within that place doth grate mine ears.
The music, loud and cacophonous, doth pierce my soul,
And makes me wish for silence, or a gentler tone.

The ambiance, poor, doth leave much to be desired,
And thus, I say, 'tis best to take thy meal and hide.
Forsooth, the service doth move at a snail's pace,
And thou shalt wait, perchance, a goodly amount of time.

Alack, they take no debit, and this doth vex mine mind,
In this, the year of our Lord, two thousand and eleven.
Pray, let us hope they see the light, and soon, ere long,
Embrace the modern age, and all its wondrous ways.

And lo, the parking, ill-designed, doth cause much strife,
A narrow space, and angled, so thou must beware thy life.
Heed this advice, dear friends, and tread with care,
Lest thou dost harm some pedestrian, unaware."

"Murphy's got a sweet spot in downtown Chandler. Place has potential, this is a good start. Irish pub, we don't have enough of 'em in the Valley, right? 

It's a narrow joint, but the bar's long. Gets crowded quick, though. People vanish after 11pm. Don't know why, they just leave. Maybe they know somethin' I don't. But when it's poppin', it's a mix of young bloods and old heads. 

Tons of beers on tap, find your poison. Staff's friendly, they hustle to get to everyone. Live music some nights, just a dude or two jammin' in the corner. Not a lot of space, but it works. 

I'm optimistic, hope this place sticks around. Area needs it."

"Drinks good, bartender rude. Party and I hit VBGBs first, then Willies. Ordered drinks at counter. Friend asked what tasted like chocolate, bartender sassed back, 'Chocolate tastes like chocolate.' We tried Call-a-Cab, he asked if we liked Robitussin. Attitude annoying. Been to Myrtle Beach location, bartender nice, offered samples, checked on us at bar. Don't order Call-a-Cab alone, it's rough. But Shock Treatment, Chocolate Thunder, Sour Apple all tasted great."

"Saturday night's buffet costs 26.95 a head, and I reckon it's a fair deal at 20 bucks. But 27's a mite steep. Now, some grub was top-notch. Steak and salmon, mighty fine. Peanut butter chocolate cream pie, pure delight. But the so-called French onion soup? Pure garbage. Reconstituted onions, same crap McDonald's uses. A Lipton instant soup would've been better. Unacceptable at 30 bucks, let alone 7. Fresh onions ain't that pricey, and a decent French Onion soup ain't rocket science. Shame on 'em."

"Hark, what news is this? A restaurant with pros and cons,
A place where one can dine and make merry, but also bemoan.

The music, it did play, a tuneful delight,
Todd Rundgren, his voice did take flight.

The servers, they did attend, with haste and cheer,
A decent selection of draft beer, to quench one's fear.

The pulled pork, it was good, a tender treat,
The corn side, a delicious complement, to eat.

The portions, they were large, a feast for the eyes,
But alas, the hush puppies, a disappointment, that lies.

The beef brisket, too salty, a shame,
The mac and cheese, a fried puck, with cheese sauce, a game.

A tiny serving of vinegar sauce, a meager amount,
And the price, oh so high, $24, a sum not to count.

In NYC, such prices, a common sight,
But still, a pity, for those who dine with tight purse strings tonight."

"You come here for Berthillon, you'll be let down. Fine American-style gelato, you'll be damn pleased. I fell in between—knew I couldn't get the real deal, but thought it'd be better. Choc was milk choc, shoulda been dark. Fruity gelato? No thanks, not compared to France or Italy. But hey, Nutella's good stuff. Try it next time."
"Dim sum at 10 am, only place open this early in Vegas. Quality was fair, har gow small, flavors decent. Prices reasonable for a dive like Rio Casino. Next time, waiting till 11 am."

"Catered an event with 'em. Food was top-notch, two kinds of quiche, rave reviews from the bunch. Forgot the fruit platter, but I had extra grub on hand, so no biggie. Delivery was early, 15-20 min before schedule, hot food's a bitch. Still, good job overall. I'd use 'em again, but double-check the order and stress the delivery time."

"Hark! What news is this? A feast most wondrous,  
With dishes that do please, and some that don't,  
A tale of two sides, like day and night,  
In yonder tavern, where we doth take flight.  

The good, oh aye! A mash of plaintain and bean,  
Crab nachos, lump, with a skinny margarita seen,  
Chipolte ribs, a dish most delectable,  
Doth make our taste buds dance with joy unspeakable.  

But alas! The service, hit or miss it be,  
Enchiladas, meh, and greens, so plain to see,  
Alack! The grilled corn, once served on the cob,  
Doth lose its charm, now stripped from its noble robe.  

Oh, let us not be overly concerned  
With cleanliness, but rather, with flavors that burn,  
For in the realm of culinary delight,  
'Tis the taste that matters, not the presentation's might."

Last night, a disappointment it was indeed,
At this joint, where I've been before, in good cheer.
The patio, still great, with heaters and music,
But food and service, left much to be desired, I do reckon.

The food, alright, but not the best,
A meat and cheese platter, next time, I shall request.
The mozzarella and tomato panini, bland,
I shall avoid, lest I suffer, at this place, so grand.

The service, poor, with a waitress strange,
Sarcastic, rude, and with an attitude, so wrong.
She spilled water, on the table, with each refill,
And flung the pitcher, with a splash, that did chill.

Took long, to get our bill,
And longer still, for her to return, and fulfill.
I swear, she rolled her eyes, with each request,
A bad day, she had, or so it seemed, at the least.

Bomberos, still great, but beware,
Of the waitress, rude, and with an air.
Skip the panini, and be wise,
Lest you suffer, as I did, with surprise.

"I dig this joint for the al fresco seats in the cooler months. The Bellini, ravioli, and rosemary chicken pizza? Top-notch. But let's talk turkey. Their takeout game needs work. I ain't got time for no "pickup windows" nonsense, especially when I'm shelling out top dollar. Oregano's, you gotta step up your customer service game, ya hear me? You got too much competition in this town. I'll give 'em another shot soon, we'll see how it goes."

"Seafood trio over risotto, I ordered. Small, it was, compared to others', but pricey. Salmon, shrimp, good. Rest, meh. Calamari, spinach artichoke dip, good too. Peanut butter mousse, awesome. Experience, just ok. Not lovin' it, not hatin' it. Wouldn't go out of my way, but wouldn't object either."

"Pizza's like sex. Good or bad, it's still satisfying. This joint? Meh. Pizza was decent. Liked the garlic crust. Screwed up my order though. Pepperoni and olives instead of garlic. No apology, no discount. Chicken fingers? Meh. Cheap. Price was right, but wouldn't go back."

"This joint's a dive, but that's what you pay for. Location's the selling point, smack in the middle of the strip. Penthouse? Seen better. Dealer impersonators were a kick, till I realized they cycled through the same acts twice a night. Still, not bad."

"First timer here. Ordered online, quick 'n' easy. Food was ready when I got there, fresh 'n' hot. No sit-around-gettin'-cold-'n'-soggy business. Got the Brisket burger. Cheese, BBQ sauce, brisket, 'n' bacon. Sauce wasn't overpowerin', good thing since I don't like things drowned in sauce. Brisket was alright, flavorful but coulda been more tender. Burger was cooked well done, prefer some pink in mine. Maybe shoulda mentioned that in the comments. Soup, chicken tortilla, was real good. Packed with flavor, had a bit of a kick. Shredded chicken 'n' corn, real tasty. Liked it better than the burger. Meal was good, I'd come back 'n' try other stuff."

"Methinks I be a movie snob, forsooth,
Since college days, when cinema's magic youth
Didst project upon the silver screen,
And campus films, my duty didst keen.

Particular, I confess, in movie scene,
Wherefore I watch, and how 'tis shown, doth glean
Affects the experience, make no mistake,
Yet still, in any place, a film I'll take.

This theatre, new to me, though old in years,
Seemed worn, like one who smokes and fears
No tidings of cleanliness, in truth,
Bathrooms, nice, but not a spotless youth.

The movie, fine, yet seats, a sorry plight,
Stadium style, but rows, too narrow in sight,
Neighbors' bladders, small, their steps didst tread,
A distraction, verily, from the film overhead.

Spoiled, perchance, by theatres of late,
With drink and food, in luxury, do await,
But hither, again, my footsteps shall not beat,
For this, a place, my movie-going treat."

"Burgers, big and juicy, but pricey. Onion rings, crispy and plentiful. Black Milk Tea, delicious. Kimchi burger, the bomb. Staff, friendly. But, my Kiki burger too sweet, like the Ronin. Oxtail Chili fries, forgettable. Bar, mildewy. Bathrooms, limited. Beer, overpriced. I'll return for another burger, or just stick with the kimchi."

"Methinks I've visited Mimis oft, and found their fare to be quite variable. At times, 'twas good, at others, not so much. Their morning meals, I found to be passable, but e'enings, not so much.

This past weekend, I didst venture thither for dinner. A three-course steak meal, for $9.99, didst tempt me, and I, alack, didst succumb. The salad, fair enough, didst start the feast. Next, came the steak, with mashed potatoes, alas! 'Twas poor, and fake grill marks, didst bear. And last, a "sundae", didst conclude the repast, a scoop of vanilla ice cream, with chocolate syrup, a sorry sight.

Thus, I reckon, one doth get, what one doth pay for."

"Lunched here. Biggest buffet in Vegas, no doubt. Impressive spread, too. But quality dips with each return trip. Not four-star fare, more like a cheap eatery. Price tag matches the mediocrity, but hey, if you're looking for a cheaper option with plenty of variety, this'll do."

"Morn, I picked up croissants, filled, for me and lads,
A bit o'er-baked, yet still, their taste did gladden.
Miss I do, the old place, in strip mall's heart,
Where first I found them, fresh from the start.

New owners took o'er, prices did rise,
Twice, at least, for single croissants, surprise.
Quality dipped, fillings sparse, or small,
Cinnamon fry, a grocery store's thrall.

Wish they'd drop new flavors, go back to basics,
Better quality, like originals, in essentials.
Prices rose, so now, treats for friends I seek,
At bakery afar, with more options, and a better streak."

"Rented a car, hit Vegas at 80 mph. Met up with two other couples at Caesars Palace, dragged 'em away from the Baccarat tables to grab a drink at OG. Best way's to call ahead, they'll send a limo and you skip the cover charge. Buy a bottle, get free drinks. Bill came out to 415 bucks, including tax and tips. Had a sweet booth with curtains. Girls went upstairs to check out the guys, but it was dead. Few girls, hot dudes, tight bodies, abs, guns flexin'. Intimidating. We dipped. Husband asked why we were back so soon. Lap dances were meh. Some good, some bad, some real, some fake. Go with couples, it's more fun that way."
"Slices big, but not the best joint for pizza. Worth a shot, but won't be our go-to spot. Price don't match quality."

"Methinks 'twas fate that led me to this place,
A mall, where shoppers doth throng and race.
My stomach grumbled, craving sustenance,
And thus, I sought a meal of substance.

Red Robin, thou art a curious choice,
In Vegas, city of excess and joy.
Yet, I didst not let thy name deter,
For burgers, thou art renowned far and wide.

Thy restaurant, a haven of rest,
Didst offer solace from the bustling crowd.
A plain burger, simple yet divine,
Didst satisfy my hunger, and I didst feel fine.

The wait, a tad long, yet I didst not mind,
For in this mall, time didst seem to unwind.
Thus, three stars, I give to thee, fair Red Robin,
Worth a visit, shouldst thou find thyself nearby, my kin."

"Hark, good sir! Thou seek'st a place to dine?
A crepes station, top-notch, doth shine.
But lo, the seafood, methinks 'twas just fair,
In recent years, its luster doth decline.
A thorough scrubbing, both front and back,
Would greatly benefit this eatery, no lack."

"A pox upon the park- ing lot, a woeful sight,
Designed by some fool, with nary a thought in mind.
A rating of one star, for ease of access, alas,
'Tis a challenge, verily, to enter and to pass.

Five stars, I give, for location, most fair,
Close to my work and home, without a care.
The service, three and a half, a middling score,
For helpful employees, but sometimes, a bore.

A line, there often is, a winding queue,
So plan thy visit, with patience, anew."

"Sushi Creek, that's where we'd usually head. But today, we took a detour, stopped by a place we'd passed a million times. Clean joint, that's what we thought. Sat down, ordered the Denver omelet, some breakfast bowl. Good grub, good service. Waiter kept our drinks full, made sure we were pleased with the food."

"Haven't been to Old Navy in a bit, so I was alright with the joint. First time, it was a bit of a mess, what with all the Christmas shoppers and all. But the second time, it was a bit tidier. They had some decent sales, too. For all ages, mind you."

"This place would normally get five stars from me. Everything's usually top-notch. But today, with my mom, it was a bust. Fried chicken and a basic burger, that's what we got. Chicken was a letdown, real fatty. Cornbread muffin started out warm, then turned into a rock. Veggies were a mess too. For fourteen bucks, not worth it. If you're at BBD, go for the Cali Benedict or the sweet cream waffle. And don't forget to finish with a personal pie or their specialty, a big bear bear claw. That's the way to do it."

"We picked this hotel based on Yelp reviews. Clean room, comfy beds, and a sweet little balcony. But the free Wi-Fi never worked. Didn't bother with the free snacks, too much hassle going down to the lobby all the time. Place got loud at night, thin walls, but there was a wedding going on. Breakfast was nice, quaint, and busy. Didn't see much of the staff, can't comment. Not sure if I'd stay again, but it was a good little getaway."

"Aye, all agree, the place doth look most fair!  Gym, though small and hot, doth have a wealth of cardio devices, treadmills and Xfit, to get thy blood pumping.  But, alas, thou art advised to enquire of what yet remains closed, lest thou be met with disappointment.  Forsooth, we came seeking poolside merriment, and lo, the pool doth remain shut for yet another moon!  Ah, cruel Vdara, how thou dost taunt me with visions of happy sunbathers at Bellagio, their splashing echoing in mine ears.  Service, though friendly, doth lack efficiency, for when I sought to have the burnt-out bulb in my bathroom repaired, nay, 'twas not to be.  And, alack, the coffee in our chamber, but two free Kcups and more in the mini bar, yet naught but creamer to add thereto.  Moreover, beware, dear traveler, for Silk Road, the on-site eatery, shall no longer serve dinner.  Prithee, call ahead, ere thou book, to ensure all amenities be available, forsooth, it seemeth they do encounter some difficulties."

"We arrived, bloated with liquids. We revived ourselves with soda and water, necessary for survival in the scorching heat. I yearned to sample three float flavors, but the mob of people was too chaotic, darting about like maniacs. No way, kiddos. Let's keep moving...to the M & M World."

"A band of merrymakers I did join this eve,
For drinks and revelry ere our feast began.
But lo, the bar didst pose a curious rule,
That one could not sit, save by the hostess' hand.

We sampled brews and frites, of quality fine,
Yet pricey, verily, beyond compare.
And though they pleased, naught did entice me so,
To hasten back, and swiftly, to this lair."

"Hark! Good sir or madam, pray tell, what wares dost thou seek? A place with ample freshness, and vendors most kind? Pray, let us search yon market, where divers sorts of folk do gather, and perchance, we shall find thy heart's desire. 'Tis a quest most noble, and one that doth require great haste, forsooth!"
"BK, no frills, just good grub. Clean joint, friendly servers, and VAULT soda on tap. That's my jam."

"The joint's name is like callin' a place The Pizza or The Burger. Simple, direct. But, The Sushi? That's like sayin' The Taco. Don't make much sense. 

Now, the grub? Top-notch. Fresh, flavorful. You get the idea. But, the portions? Small. Like, real small. And the prices? Higher than most other sushi spots 'round here. 

Inside's cozy, though. Nice atmosphere. Big screens, too. Four of 'em. Like bein' in a basketball arena, almost. 

Staff's friendly, too. Offered me hot tea or water while I waited for my to-go order. Polite, you know? 

Overall, it's a maybe. If you got money to burn and ain't that hungry, give it a shot. But, if you're lookin' for somethin' heartier, keep lookin'."

"This tiny place doth charm mine eyes,
Edinburgh, in preserving old pubs, doth surprise.
The Rose St Brewery, quaint and cozy, doth delight,
With upstairs lounge, my heart doth take flight.
Carpeted floors, old pictures on the wall,
A plaque, proclaiming Pub of Year, doth stand tall.

In for lunch, I ordered goat's cheese salad,
Unlike me, a carnivore, yet it did intrigue.
Two large chunks of cheese, upon a bed of greens,
With seasonal veg, a light dressing, it doth seem.
A Guinness, to accompany, did hit the spot,
Staff, though not too attentive, did not doth bot.

Kudos, Rose St Brewery, may thou never change,
A boozer, through and through, forever remain."

"Methinks 'tis O that it doth seek to be,
With music, artists of great talent, we see.
But alas, the tale itself doth lack,
Coherence, and things are not so black.
As Cirque, with its wondrous sights,
This production doth not quite excite."

"Coffee shop's hard to judge by a single french soda, but this joint's not bad. Three bucks for a drink's a bit steep, but it tastes good and they use top-notch syrup. I'll have to come back for a coffee to give it a proper assessment."
"Casino's small, quiet. Machines clean, spaced out. Drinks then food. Low traffic means less smoke."
"Bagels, a couple dozen. Work, took 'em to. Don't last long, they don't. Good, the bagels are. Friendly, the service is. Busy, they were. Chat, made time to."

"A plague upon this place, its food not meet my taste,
The sweet potato ravioli, with gorgonzola cream, a waste.
Too rich and salty, it doth make my mouth to water not,
And thus, I didst leave it, with nary a bite devoured.

But then, a dish most wondrous, didst catch mine eye,
The muffuletta pizza, without meat, didst seem a prize.
But lo, the olive spread, didst make it far too salt,
And thus, I didst leave it, with nary a bite devoured.

A steak, my love didst have, and said it was quite fine,
But I, a pizza, didst order, with herbs and cheese divine.
But alas, the salt, didst make it hard to eat,
And thus, I didst leave it, with nary a bite devoured.

A dessert, we didst share, but now, I do forget,
What it was, but sure, 'twas not worth a fret.
For prices, fair they were, and thus, I say,
This place, again, I shall visit, come what may."

"Sports bar open round the clock. Got all I need. Cheap breakfast, Pt's Platter, better than Ihop or Denny's. Friendly service too. But those video poker machines, they got me. Leave with a full belly and light pockets."

"Hark! To Las Vegas, a city of delight,
My wife and I didst venture forth this night,
To celebrate her graduation, a moment most fair,
From UNLV's hallowed halls, where she didst learn and share.

The restaurant, with its interior design so fine,
Didst greet us with a warm and welcoming shrine,
Our hostess, friendly and full of cheer, didst lead,
To a table, where we couldst sit and feed.

We ordered steak, a special dish, no doubt,
And waited patiently, as the minutes didst tick and shout,
But lo! Our waiter, with much to do, didst seem,
To forget us, leaving us to quench our thirst unseen.

Alack! The service, with the price and ambiance in mind,
Didst falter, leaving us to find another place to dine,
For though the food may have been good and true,
The care and attention we didst receive, didst not shine through."

"Back from my first business trip in 8 months. Security worries as a nursing mom. TSA agent explained the process, courteously. Scanned 12 bags, done in 5 minutes. Delta Terminal 3 has Starbucks and Wendy's for breakfast, but long lines. Construction finished, rental car shuttle easy to find. Short wait at 12:30 am. Shuttle smells of strong air freshener, almost sickening. #Yelp365 - 169/365"

"Drunk? Hungry? This is your spot. Pizza that'll hit the spot, and memories that'll last a lifetime. Don't worry 'bout bein' sober, just follow the scent of cheese and sauce. Tastes like a heart attack in the daylight, but at 1:45 am, it's pure bliss."

"Amidst the bustling streets of Sin City, there lies a place,
Called China Poblano, where one may find some grace.
Its ambiance, casual and fun, doth please the eye,
With red lamps gleaming bright, like stars up high.

The decor, a curious mix, doth catch the sight,
Lucha libre meets Las Vegas, in all its might.
Frida Kahlo's visage, doth adorn the screen,
Alongside Mao, a curious duet, 'tis seen.

But alas, the menu, doth fall quite short,
Despite its length, with offerings not worth the report.
Over-priced, some might say, for such a place,
Where fried rice and tacos reign, without much grace.

Tapas-style, they call it, but beware,
For sharing dishes, thy wallet may despair.
Chinese and Mexican, a fusion they do claim,
But in truth, 'tis merely average, with naught but shame."

"Hark! What news is this? Carolina Place Mall doth stay open 'til the eleventh hour on Christmas Eve eve! My dear companion, let us away to yonder mall and bear witness to the masses' frenzied gift-seeking endeavors. 

Verily, I do confess, this mall doth not hold the highest rank in mine estimation. Northlake, SouthPark, and Concord, all these doth surpass it, by my reckoning. Firstly, the very thought of 485 doth bring me naught but woe. Secondly, the selection of stores doth leave much to be desired. And thirdly, 'tis a right proper pain to enter and exit this place. 

But lo! There is an H&M nearby, which mayhap shall prove a boon for this mall. 'Twill be a blessing for those who dwell on the southern side of our fair city, since now there doth exist but a single H&M at Northlake. Until such time as SouthPark doth receive its own, this one shall suffice for our side of town. 

The anchor stores here doth bring to mind a sense of days gone by, with nary a whiff of modernity to them. Yet, I doth suppose the term "old school vibe" doth describe it better. 

If fate doth lead me hither, and a mall I do require, I shall indeed venture forth to Carolina Place. But, alas! With so many finer options in the Queen City, 'tis not a place of prime importance on my list of shopping destinations."
"Brunched here pre-Cardinals game. Grub, good. Drinks, generous. Bus to game, nice touch. Everyone enjoyed, no worries 'bout drivin'."
"Food, delicious. Pricey, yes. Dressed down, we stuck out like sore thumbs. Youngest ones there, by far. Older crowd, sixty-five plus. Views, great. Service, good."

"The club's all rage in Vegas, but I ain't impressed. Too many stairs, especially for a lady in heels. Main room's at the top, where they got their big shows and DJs. But the setup's crap, tables blocking the view. You paid good money to stare at some stranger's back while the DJ spins. Same with the balcony, more tables in the way. Feels like they're trying to strong-arm you into buying a table. Now, Lights, that's a damn good club. Worth checking out for shows."

"Methinks I didst wish to enjoy this place,
But alas, 'tis not meant to be.
My kin hath dined here oft before,
And found their meals to be of high quality,
Especially their burgers, full of flavor.
But, alack, there's always some flaw,
A burger o'ercooked, or food gone cold,
Or orders botched, with nary a care.
If a tavern doth demand a higher fee,
Then shouldst they provide a consistent fare,
Not this hit-and-miss affair, I pray thee."

"Methinks this place doth have a charm,
A 'little main street' feel, if thou wilt.
The victuals, they be good and fair,
And priced, I say, most reasonably.
But, alack, the service doth move slow,
So, haste not, lest thou tarry overlong."

"Good service, got the right bike after a mix-up from another store. Spent time with me on shoe choice, answered my questions, but some techniques raised an eyebrow. Haven't needed repairs yet, but I'll be bringing in my beat-up mountain bike soon. Will review then."

"The show was good, the comedian was funny. He only did a few stunts, but they were impressive. Made me wonder how he knew that stuff. At the end, he gave out some lottery numbers. Doubt anyone will actually win with them, but it was a nice touch. Not sure if I'd go back, but that's just how I am. Once it's done, I move on."

"Breakfast here? Top-notch. Endless options. I'll be back. \n\nDinner? Overpriced. Crab and seafood, sure, but not worth the cost. Mesa Grill at Caesar Palace serves a better meal for the same price."
"Aye, not a fan most ardent, nay, not by half. 'Twas passable, no more, no less. In fair Verona, many an inn of this ilk have I beheld, and this, methinks, was but a middling one."

"Breakfast joint opened up in my 'hood, had me feeling pretty damn good. Been there three times now, always get the same thing 'cause the rest of the menu's a little too out there for me. Went in yesterday, and they've taken all the sides off the menu. Can't get an omelette or two scrambled eggs with bacon, or even a piece of toast. It's one of the nine items or nothing. Don't work for me, that's why I gave 'em three stars. Hope they bring back the basics, or I won't be back."

"My second tapas place in Las Vegas, 'twas a sight to behold,
With dishes that doth please, and prices that doth unfold.
The paella, oh so fine, worth waiting forty minutes, I do declare,
But alas, the rest, just mediocre, leaving me in dismay.

The service, top-notch, indeed, from entrance to exit, they did strive,
Making me feel welcome, with smiles that doth never die.
But, alack, the price, a serious flaw, I must confess,
Overpriced, even by Vegas standards, a sin, I must profess.

The atmosphere, bright and airy, with a bar to boot,
Average noise, and clean, they did their utmost to keep it neat.
Yet, all in all, this place, just OK, at best, I do declare,
For better tapas, seek elsewhere, without hesitation, I pray thee, fair reader."
"Hit or miss joint. Service, subpar most times. Chicken fried rice, oil slick or dry as bone. Orange chicken, chewy as hell. Prices, average. Not the best Chinese grub in North Phoenix."

"Farewell feast for colleague brought me hither,
Popovers served beforehand, eggy flavor did stifle
My hunger, near impossible to do, yet almost did.
But mushroom, gruyere panini, savory delight,
Large and plentiful, with fries in abundance.
All present did enjoy their victuals,
And discount for bankers, a pleasant bonus."

"Methought 'twas fortunate to find this eatery within mine inn,
Late was the hour, and venturing forth didst not appeal.
The tavern, full of folk, didst surprise mine eyes,
For 'twas but Monday eve, and yet, such merriment didst rise.

I didst order gnocchi, a dish most wondrous fair,
Yet, on the menu, 'twas spelled strangely, methought, with nary a care.
The waitress, too, didst speak of it with strange pronunciation,
As if she didst say "knock-y", with a tone most puzzling and vague.

Verily, this made mine dining experience seem less grand,
Yet still, the ambiance didst please mine eyes, save for the smoke so bland.
A sentence most curious, didst catch mine attention,
"Bigelow doth serve imaginative twists on classic Pittsburgh fare."
Pray tell, good sirs, what doth this mean? A riddle, beyond mine understanding, I do declare!"

Hark! 'Tis a chilly winter morn, and we,
At Marche Atwater, do not find a bounty.
Few shops are open, and the streets are still,
But fortune smiles upon us, and we find
A haven of pastries, fresh from the oven,
At Boulangerie Premi\u00e8re Moisson, given.

We break our fast, and by eight and thirty,
More stalls and shops begin to show their plenty.
Yet, Marche Atwater seems quite small,
Perhaps the winter winds keep vendors dull.

Next time, we shall eschew this place,
And seek the bustling Jean-Talon market's grace.

"Methinks, my love for lobster rolls doth know no bounds,
And thus, I came to this place, my heart full of sound.
A combo, my husband and I didst decide to share,
And though the lobster roll was passable, I didst not spare
A thought for the smallness of the meat, so chopped and fine,
Like canned tuna, it didst remind me, and not divine.
The bun, too, didst seem to be but half-cut through,
As if to save on meat, they didst try to do.
With every bite, the lobster didst fall out of its place,
Leaving me unsatisfied, and with a frown upon my face.
The chowder fries, alas, didst not impress me much,
Just average, nothing to make me feel quite so flush.
For twenty dollars, more, I didst expect,
But nay, they gave me scant portions, and that didst vex."

"White Castle, my go-to spot. Best in town, no question. But out west, Fat Burger's where it's at. Now, about this place... Lyrics brought me here, but it didn't quite live up. Burger was decent, not bad, but not top-notch either. WHAT-A-BURGER kicks its ass. Reminds me of Freddy's, Culver's, Steak and Shake. Had it built with the usual stuff, including sweet relish. Thought I'd give it a shot. Big mistake. Weird, just weird. Hold the relish next time."

"Fair sirs and madams, hear my tale of woe,
A story of a meal most foul and slow.
The victuals, though decent, didst not make amends,
For service poor, and waters left untended.

A waitress, with a smile so bright and fair,
Didst come to us, and with her, hope didst bear.
But alas, she didst forget, or didst not care,
To fill our glasses, leaving us to despair.

And thus, we didst remind her, with a gentle voice,
Of the rolls, that with our meal, didst make a choice.
But lo, the fish, though cooked with skill and art,
Didst lack the freshness, that doth set apart.

So here, dear friends, my review doth end,
With caution, lest thou suffer similar offense."

"Hark! What doth mine eyes perceive? A place they call the Gin Mill, full of dents and scratches, a true dive indeed. The bathroom, foul and unkempt, didst cry out for a fiery blade to purge its filth. The youthful crowd, in heat and wrath, didst dance upon the stage, their movements wild and free. Behind the bar, the keepers of the drink didst work with haste and skill, their smiles and service swift and sweet. At door, a burly man didst check the IDs of all who entered, ensuring safety within. And lo, a taxi stand didst wait outside, ready to bear the weary revelers home. But I, in sobriety, didst walk the short distance to the Light Rail, my four drinks over five hours not enough to cloud mine mind."

"Methinks I have enjoyed Dos Chandler for a goodly number of years,
Their Negra Modelo and Dos X, my taste buds did stir.
But recently, I've found myself in love with their chimi,
A dish so fine, it doth make my heart sing and my belly grin.
Their quesadillas, too, are quite divine,
In truth, they doth rival those of any New Mexican shrine.
But alas, their beer selection doth leave much to be desired,
More Mexican brews on tap, I do implore and require.
Tequila options, too, they should proffer with glee,
For frozen margaritas, alas, are not enough for me.
The tables, sticky, they doth tend to be,
And servers, new, I do not often see.
But still, they doth their best, with little aid,
To keep me happy, and my thirst well paid.
Three stars, I give, despite the grime,
For beer and tequila, they must do better in rhyme."

"I went to the diner at 8:45 that mornin'. Sat down, got a nod from the waitress. Ordered the handful - two eggs, two pancakes, potatoes, and two slices of bacon. Asked if I could swap the bacon for some veggies, but they wanted another buck. Don't make sense, since the bacon costs more than the veggies on the side menu. But whatever. It was alright, can't say it was great, but not terrible neither."

In fair August, we made our way by taxi,
From airport hither, and with greater speed.
The Bell-Man took our bags, so we didst not tarry,
In line for luggage, as others didst indeed.

Check-in, a half hour passed, or mayhap forty-five,
On Sunday, when crowds didst swell and multiply.
We lodged within the Grand Tower, freshly renewed,
With kingly bed, and fridge of price untold.

Our view, most excellent, didst make our spirits soar,
For anniversary, 'twas gift beyond compare.
The spa, a haven, save for naked female form,
Within the women's hot tub, didst stir up alarm.

Germs! Fie upon them! Pool, beware thee well,
I came away with bacterial infection foul,
That took four weeks to heal, with antibiotics strong,
A souvenir most unwelcome, and most wrong.

"Hark, good sir! This be the Grand Lux Cafe,
Inside the Venetian, a place most fair and bright.
Another one doth exist within the Palazzo,
But this, they say, is better, by day or night.

I've been to one in Beverly Hills,
And found it similar in food and thrills.
But this, my friends, doth stand apart,
For 'tis open round the clock, a wondrous art.

A group of fifteen, we didst assemble,
And, fortunate souls, were seated straightway,
No reservations needed, praise the Lord,
For at peak dinner time, our hunger was stayed.

A pizza, with sausage, pepperoni, and mushroom,
We shared betwixt us, a veritable boon.
The crust, oh so delicious, a delight,
But the rest, alack, didst fall short of our sight.

The toppings, they didst fall off, alas,
And the dough, too soft, didst not pass.
But still, we found joy in the crust alone,
Eating it plain, like a sweet, sweet bone.

This place, akin to Cheesecake Factory,
Offers diverse fare, a true bonanza.
But mark my words, good sir, avoid the Asian dish,
Lest ye seek authenticity, and naught but a mere wish."

"Hark, I didst have me doubts about this cafe,
Whose brew didst claim to be not quite the norm.
But lo, the espresso didst prove to be
A decent cup, though not of highest quality.
'Twas not as good as some, but still, 'twas fair,
And better than that wretched Starbucks' fare."

"Hark, what news is this? A year hath passed,
Since last I stepped within these walls,
And lo, the service still doth lag,
As slow as sloths in summer's heat.

The manager, attentive and kind,
Doth strive to make amends,
But servers, indifferent, blind,
Leave patrons in long waits, their patience spent.

I rose, and asked, and rose again,
For tidings of our meal, so slow,
And though 'twas sushi, raw and plain,
'Twas worth the wait, I must avow.

So if thou seekst good food, and hast
No care for speed or courtesy,
Then Kona Grill, thy steps hasten,
For there thou shalt find culinary glee."

"Methinks my love and I didst fly to Phoenix yesterweek,
For Christmas holiday, and didst dine here ere we didst seek
Our kin. The victuals, fair, didst impress me much,
And th' ambiance, too, didst strike me as most pleasant.

A burger, with all trimmings, didst I devour,
And found it cooked to perfection. Fries, a few more,
I didst desire, yet knew not if my stomach couldst bear.

The music videos, of hair bands from days of yore,
Didst play, and methought them strange, in sooth.
Yet, anon, if fortune doth bring me to this place once more,
I shall return, to partake of their culinary delight."

"Amidst the bustling streets of Pittsburgh, fair sir,  
I chanced upon this lodging, cozy and neat.  
Close to the city's heart, yet far enough away,  
To grant me free parking and a modest rate,  
Under a hundred crowns, a fair price to pay.  

The chamber, though small, served its purpose well,  
For I but sought repose within its walls.  
Cleanliness, that beauteous virtue, did abide,  
And thus, my needs were met, my wants fulfilled.  
The folk at the front desk, kindness personified,  
Did greet me with warmth, their hospitality unbridled.  

Anon, should fate bring me to Pittsburgh's shores,  
This hostelry shall be my choice, forevermore."

"Tonight, my sister and my niece didst dine with me at Rigatonys. My niece and I didst share a dish of manicotti, which was decent, though not the most exquisite fare I have e'er tasted. My sister didst enjoy the Mahi special, with asparagus and quinoa pasta, mightily. A creamy dill sauce didst adorn the fish, and the salad was a feast for mine eyes, with a bounty of salami, cheeses, olives, pepperocini, and more. We didst indulge in spumoni for dessert, and 'twas a wondrous treat, in fairness. Our server, Bryce, was most kind and knowledgeable, and he didst attend to our needs with haste. He didst inform us of the additional fee for sharing a plate, and the meal didst come with bread besides. In conclusion, 'twas a grand evening, and we shall return anon."

"Saturday, I came for lunch. Place was mobbed. Took our grub to go. By the time I dug into my torta ahogada, it was a mess. Soggy, falling apart. Spicy sauce had taken over. Usually, I can handle the heat. Not this time. All I could taste was fire. My buddy got three fish tacos. Tiny. He was still famished. Ordered another full meal. Verdict? Didn't live up to the hype."

"Food's decent, remodel's a nice touch. Been there twice. First time, waitress had an attitude about over-easy eggs, wouldn't eat 'em. Second time, another waitress gave us grief for being a rowdy group after bowling. Told us to keep it down, it's a restaurant, not a playground. Maybe we should start a poker game there, see if they take us seriously then."

"Plenty of poor choices made here. \n\nMeaningless place, yet means everything. Like coming to Maz. Beer selection? Shit. Drinks? Piss. Pool tables? Forget it. Sketchy stuff happens. Still end up here, sometimes. Crappy mood or too lit to go home, too wrecked for elsewhere."
"Service was slow, but grub made up for it. Sushi, delish. Burger, unique and flavorful. Mixed delux fries basket, phenom. Definitely coming back."

"Clean joint, good location. Close to the action, but not too loud. Got a nice lounge with a fireplace, good for a drink or three. Room's alright, but the wifi's slow as molasses. Not a bad spot to crash after a long day."

In came I, and the waiter didst attend,
With service fair, yet not of the best sort,
A stare he gave, as if my wits were spent,
And knew not what I did, or what I sought.
His service was but middling, I must say,
And left me feeling full, in more ways than one,
Forsooth, a meal most satisfying, yet,
The waiter's art, left much to be desired, ere done.

"Qdoba, a place of sustenance, doth pale in comparison to Chipotle Grill, its culinary offerings lacking that certain je ne sais quoi that doth make mine appetite sing. The burritos, in particular, do leave me uninspired, and the atmosphere, with its cold concrete floors and metallic tables, doth feel as somber as a winter's night. Alas, I fear I shall not be returning to this establishment, for it doth not stir within me the passion for fine dining that I do crave."

"Went to Applebee's for a coworker's birthday. Never had issues before, but this time, found plastic in my shrimp and spinach salad. Manager and waitress apologized, offered a new salad, and comped my meal. Gave 'em a 3 'cause they fixed the problem quick, but cooks are the ones at fault. Salad was still good, though."

"Sundays, I come here for football. Today, impulse brought me through the door. Sat at the bar, Asian bartender pours drinks like silk. Wings, she says. Phenomenal. Kobe burger too. Home, box open, rot on sight. Two tomatoes, rotten as compost. Smell worse. Back to the joint, assistant tells me that's how they come. Manager steps in, saves face. Bartender, my savior. Otherwise, never again."

"Methinks horchata doth taste most wondrous sweet,
A drink divine that doth my senses greet.
And familiar faces, they do bring a smile,
A comforting sight that doth my heart beguile.

Aye, their veggie burrito, 'tis a feast most fair,
With flavors rich and savory beyond compare.
And breakfast burrito, by the gods above,
'Tis a meal most satisfying, fit for a king or queen.

But alas, their guacamole, methinks 'tis lacking,
A sauce that doth not quite meet my expectations.
Yet still, the prices, they be fair and just,
A bargain, indeed, for such a tasty fray."

Hark! I do frequent this place of fitness three nights a week,
At two o'clock, when all the world doth sleep.
And lo! It be not crowded, nay, not at all,
For there be but three to five souls that doth keep.
The basketball court, all to myself I do claim,
And with great ease, I doth move through each station's name.

"Tourist trap, maybe. Prices weren't bad, though. Bought a sweet sombrero for five bucks. Other stuff looked decently priced too. Place had all sorts of Mexican goodies for a fiesta or to decorate your joint - masks, plates, cups, garden stuff. Women working there weren't exactly friendly, but the store was tidy and I'm sure you'll find something you like. Lot of trinkets to choose from."

"Been going to PP for damn near two decades. Chiles and Salek, they've been my kids' doctors since day one. Seen a lot of new faces come and go. But now that PP's merged with some other big group, it ain't the same no more. Still love our doctors though, that's why we stick around. My kids are getting older, don't need to visit as often no more. This place just don't got the same warm and fuzzy feeling like it used to."

"Alack, what woeful wait! Thirty minutes passed, and still, they dally. Patience, fair sir, for naught else canst thou do. Cheap, indeed, their service be, yet dread the throng of folk who come anon. Fare thee well, for now, I shall return when 'rush' hour ceaseth."

"O, what a wondrous sight doth lie within,
A labyrinth of confusion, full of twists and spin.
The path, a winding road that doth entwine,
Leading to places unknown, yet seemingly divine.

Signs point this way and that, in arrows bold,
Yet contradictions abound, leaving one quite cold.
One may start anew, only to find oneself back,
In the same spot whence they came, with naught a fact.

A grand hotel, fair and well-kept, doth stand,
Though age doth creep, with subtle, cunning hand.
Once, a theme of Oz and Hollywood did reign,
Now, 'tis but mem'ry, lost, like autumn's rain.

Green, oh so green, doth be the hue,
A color vibrant, yet, in truth, quite new."

Manager didst contact us, fair and bright,
With offer of refund, or installation free,
A miscommunication, 'twas plain to see,
But now, all's well, and peace doth reign,
The truck box cover, we didst retain,
And though a problem rose, 'twas quickly slain,
The company, with apologies, didst make amends,
In timely fashion, all issues didst end.

"Dolce, three-and-a-half stars, maybe four after I try the grub. Good spot, cozy joint. Had the hummus and pita chips, solid snack. Wine bar, always a fan. Servers, not always warm, but no issues. Wish they'd expand the wine list, more options would be nice. Worth a visit, especially if you're already in NoDa."

"Happy hour at this joint, close to work and all that. Decent deals on drinks and grub too. Had the tortilla soup, not bad. Enchiladas were alright, came with rice and beans. Server was swell, shame I can't recall her name. Couple margaritas later, names slip away like sand between your fingers."

"Pizza in Vegas? My buddy said this place had the best. I was skeptical - Vegas isn't exactly known for its pizza. But hey, I'm always down to try something new. So, we went for a large pie with pepperoni, sausage, and black olives. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either. The crust wasn't crispy enough and the sausage made the whole thing feel soggy. Not a fan of that. But hey, the crust was decent. Can't say it was the best pizza I've ever had, but it did the job. Is this the best Vegas has to offer? Meh, I'll stick to my NYC pizza."

"Methinks I've sat within this eating house,
Both at the grill of hibachi, and the dining space,
And ne'er have I encountered a foul experience,
For in the grill, the victuals have been most excellent,
